examples: after his departure, there was an interval of many years without any meetings
the intervals between meals were very short

noun.description: A pause or break in activity.
A space between two things; a gap.
The difference in pitch between two musical sounds.

phrases: After she had chewed most of the sandwich, she continued, still swallowing at intervals.
Attendees are served white rum and strong coffee at intervals throughout the event, which may continue well into the night.
They had clung to each other for warmth through the night, with Michael flashing his torch into the darkness at intervals.
Tallages continued to be demanded at intervals until 1340, when Edward III agreed that the consent of Parliament must be obtained.
origin: Middle English: from Old French entrevalle, based on Latin intervallum space between ramparts, interval, from inter- between + vallum rampart.
